code: export const techniques=[{id:"armbar",name:"Armbar (Juji Gatame)",category:"Submissions",origin:"The armbar is one of the most fundamental submissions in BJJ, originating from traditional Japanese Jiu-Jitsu. It was adapted and refined by the Gracie family in Brazil, becoming a cornerstone technique in modern BJJ. The name 'Juji Gatame' comes from Japanese, where 'Juji' means cross and 'Gatame' means lock.",description:"The armbar is a joint lock that hyperextends the elbow joint by placing the opponent's arm between your legs and applying pressure. From guard, mount, or side control, you isolate one arm, secure it between your thighs, and arch your hips to create the submission. The key is controlling the opponent's posture and preventing them from stacking or escaping.",bestResponse:"The best defense against an armbar is to prevent it before it's fully locked. Keep your elbows close to your body, maintain good posture, and never let your opponent isolate your arm. If caught, immediately try to stack the opponent, grab your own gi or belt to relieve pressure, or roll to escape. Always protect your arm by keeping it bent and close to your chest."},{id:"triangle-choke",name:"Triangle Choke (Sankaku Jime)",category:"Submissions",origin:"The triangle choke was developed in Judo and later perfected in BJJ. It's named for the triangular shape created by your legs around the opponent's neck and arm. The technique became popular in BJJ due to its effectiveness from the guard position and was famously used by many Gracie family members.",description:"The triangle choke is a blood choke that cuts off blood flow to the brain by compressing the carotid arteries. You wrap your legs around the opponent's neck and one arm, creating a figure-four lock with your legs. The key is proper angle and hip movement to create maximum pressure on the neck while controlling the opponent's posture.",bestResponse:"To defend the triangle, immediately posture up and try to stack the opponent. Keep your head up and your arm that's inside the triangle close to your body. If you can't escape, try to pass the guard to relieve pressure. Never let your opponent control your posture or get the proper angle for the choke."},{id:"rear-naked-choke",name:"Rear Naked Choke (Hadaka Jime)",category:"Submissions",origin:"The rear naked choke is one of the oldest and most effective submission techniques, originating from traditional Japanese martial arts. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a fundamental technique for back control. The name 'Hadaka Jime' means 'naked strangle' in Japanese, referring to the fact that no gi is needed.",description:"The rear naked choke is applied from the back position, where you wrap your arm around the opponent's neck and secure it with your other arm. The technique cuts off blood flow to the brain by compressing the carotid arteries. The key is proper hand placement, keeping your elbows close, and using your body weight to apply pressure.",bestResponse:"The best defense is to prevent your opponent from taking your back. If they do get back control, immediately protect your neck with your hands and try to peel their arms off. Keep your chin down and try to turn into them to relieve pressure. If caught in the choke, tap immediately as it can cause unconsciousness quickly."},{id:"kimura",name:"Kimura Lock (Gyaku Ude Garami)",category:"Submissions",origin:"The Kimura lock is named after Masahiko Kimura, the legendary Japanese Judoka who famously used it to defeat Helio Gracie in 1951. The technique was originally called 'Gyaku Ude Garami' in Judo, meaning 'reverse arm entanglement.' It became a fundamental technique in BJJ and is now one of the most versatile submissions.",description:"The Kimura is a shoulder lock that applies pressure to the shoulder joint by controlling the opponent's wrist and applying rotational force. It can be applied from various positions including guard, side control, and mount. The key is controlling the opponent's wrist, keeping it close to their body, and using your body weight to apply the lock.",bestResponse:"To defend the Kimura, keep your elbows close to your body and never let your opponent isolate your arm. If they do get the grip, immediately try to roll or escape before they secure the position. You can also try to counter with your own Kimura or use the grip to sweep or pass guard."},{id:"guillotine",name:"Guillotine Choke",category:"Submissions",origin:"The guillotine choke is a fundamental front headlock submission that has been used in various grappling arts for centuries. It became particularly popular in BJJ due to its effectiveness against aggressive opponents and its versatility from various positions. The name comes from the French execution device due to the similar action of the choke.",description:"The guillotine is a front headlock where you wrap your arm around the opponent's neck and apply pressure with your body weight. It can be applied as a blood choke or air choke depending on the variation. The key is proper hand placement, keeping your elbow close to your body, and using your hips to apply pressure.",bestResponse:"To defend the guillotine, immediately try to pass the guard or stack the opponent. Keep your head up and try to posture out of the choke. If you can't escape, try to roll to relieve pressure. Never let your opponent control your posture or get the proper angle for the choke."},{id:"omoplata",name:"Omoplata (Ashi Sankaku Garami)",category:"Submissions",origin:"The omoplata is a shoulder lock that originated in Judo as 'Ashi Sankaku Garami' (leg triangle entanglement). It was adapted and refined in BJJ, particularly by the Gracie family. The name 'omoplata' comes from the Portuguese word for 'shoulder blade,' which is the target of the technique.",description:"The omoplata is a shoulder lock that uses your leg to control the opponent's arm and apply pressure to their shoulder joint. From guard, you wrap your leg around the opponent's arm and use your hips to create the lock. The technique can also be used as a sweep or transition to other submissions.",bestResponse:"To defend the omoplata, immediately try to roll or escape before your opponent secures the position. Keep your arm close to your body and try to posture up. If caught, you can try to roll to relieve pressure or use the position to counter with your own techniques."},{id:"heel-hook",name:"Heel Hook",category:"Submissions",origin:"The heel hook is a leg lock that has been used in various grappling arts for centuries. It became particularly popular in modern BJJ and submission grappling due to its effectiveness and the rise of leg lock specialists. The technique targets the knee joint and can cause serious injury if applied incorrectly.",description:"The heel hook is a leg lock that applies rotational force to the knee joint by controlling the opponent's heel and twisting. It can be applied from various positions including the saddle, 50/50, and other leg entanglement positions. The key is proper control of the opponent's leg and applying the lock gradually.",bestResponse:"The best defense is to prevent your opponent from securing leg control. If they do get a leg lock position, immediately try to escape or counter. Keep your legs active and try to prevent them from isolating your leg. If caught in a heel hook, tap immediately as it can cause serious knee injury."},{id:"de-la-riva-guard",name:"De La Riva Guard",category:"Guard",origin:"The De La Riva guard was developed by Ricardo De La Riva, a Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu black belt under Carlson Gracie. He created this innovative guard variation in the 1980s, which uses a hook behind the opponent's leg to control their movement and create sweeping opportunities. The technique revolutionized modern BJJ guard play.",description:"The De La Riva guard is an open guard variation where you hook your leg behind the opponent's leg while controlling their sleeve and collar. This creates a strong control point that allows for various sweeps and submissions. The key is maintaining proper distance, controlling the opponent's posture, and using the hook to off-balance them.",bestResponse:"To counter the De La Riva guard, immediately try to remove the hook by stepping back or using your free leg to kick it off. Control the opponent's legs and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them establish control of your sleeves or collar, and maintain good posture to prevent sweeps."},{id:"berimbolo",name:"Berimbolo",category:"Guard",origin:"The berimbolo was developed by the Mendes brothers (Rafael and Guilherme) in the early 2000s. It's a modern guard technique that involves inverting and rolling to take the opponent's back. The name 'berimbolo' comes from a Brazilian Portuguese word meaning 'trick' or 'gimmick,' reflecting its innovative nature.",description:"The berimbolo is a complex guard technique that involves inverting your body and rolling to take the opponent's back. It's typically set up from De La Riva guard or other open guard positions. The key is proper grip control, timing the inversion, and maintaining control throughout the movement.",bestResponse:"To defend the berimbolo, immediately try to prevent the inversion by controlling the opponent's legs and maintaining good posture. Don't let them establish the necessary grips, and try to pass the guard before they can set up the technique. If they do invert, try to counter with your own techniques."},{id:"butterfly-guard",name:"Butterfly Guard",category:"Guard",origin:"The butterfly guard was developed in BJJ as a way to create space and generate power for sweeps. It's named for the butterfly-like movement of the legs when executing sweeps. The technique became popular due to its effectiveness in both gi and no-gi competition.",description:"The butterfly guard is an open guard variation where you place your feet in the opponent's hips or thighs and use your legs to control their movement. It's excellent for creating sweeps and maintaining distance. The key is proper foot placement, controlling the opponent's posture, and using your legs to generate power for sweeps.",bestResponse:"To counter the butterfly guard, immediately try to control the opponent's legs and prevent them from establishing hooks. Use pressure to flatten them out and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them control your posture or get the proper angle for sweeps."},{id:"half-guard",name:"Half Guard",category:"Guard",origin:"The half guard is one of the oldest and most fundamental guard variations in BJJ. It's a transitional position that occurs when the opponent has passed part of your guard but you still have one leg trapped. The technique has been refined over decades and remains a crucial position in modern BJJ.",description:"The half guard is a position where you have one leg trapped between the opponent's legs while the other leg is free. It's excellent for sweeps, submissions, and regaining full guard. The key is controlling the opponent's posture, using your free leg effectively, and creating opportunities to sweep or submit.",bestResponse:"When in top half guard, immediately try to flatten the opponent and prevent them from regaining full guard. Control their upper body and try to pass quickly. Don't let them establish grips or create space for sweeps. Use pressure to control the position."},{id:"closed-guard",name:"Closed Guard",category:"Guard",origin:"The closed guard is the most fundamental guard position in BJJ, originating from traditional Japanese Jiu-Jitsu. It was adapted and refined by the Gracie family and remains the foundation of BJJ guard play. The position is named for the closed nature of the legs around the opponent.",description:"The closed guard is a position where you wrap your legs around the opponent's waist and lock your ankles together. It's excellent for controlling the opponent, setting up submissions, and preventing them from passing. The key is maintaining the guard, controlling the opponent's posture, and using your legs and hips effectively.",bestResponse:"To pass the closed guard, immediately try to break the guard by standing up or using pressure. Control the opponent's hips and prevent them from controlling your posture. Don't let them establish grips or set up submissions. Use proper technique to open the guard and pass quickly."},{id:"mount",name:"Mount Position",category:"Positions",origin:"The mount position is one of the most dominant positions in grappling, originating from traditional Japanese martial arts. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a fundamental position for control and submissions. The position is named for the mounted position, similar to riding a horse.",description:"The mount is a dominant position where you sit on the opponent's chest with your legs on either side of their body. It's excellent for control and setting up various submissions including armbars, triangles, and chokes. The key is maintaining proper balance, controlling the opponent's arms, and preventing escapes.",bestResponse:"To escape the mount, immediately try to bridge and roll or use the elbow escape. Keep your arms close to your body and try to create space. Don't let the opponent establish control or set up submissions. Use proper technique to escape and regain guard."},{id:"side-control",name:"Side Control",category:"Positions",origin:"Side control is a fundamental position in grappling that has been used in various martial arts for centuries. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a crucial position for control and submissions. The position is named for the side-by-side nature of the bodies.",description:"Side control is a dominant position where you lie perpendicular to the opponent, controlling their upper body with your weight and positioning. It's excellent for control and setting up various submissions including kimuras, armbars, and chokes. The key is maintaining proper pressure and preventing escapes.",bestResponse:"To escape side control, immediately try to bridge and roll or use the shrimp escape. Keep your arms close to your body and try to create space. Don't let the opponent establish control or set up submissions. Use proper technique to escape and regain guard."},{id:"back-control",name:"Back Control",category:"Positions",origin:"Back control is one of the most dominant positions in grappling, originating from traditional Japanese martial arts. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became the ultimate position for control and submissions. The position is named for the control of the opponent's back.",description:"Back control is a dominant position where you control the opponent's back, typically with hooks in their legs and control of their upper body. It's excellent for setting up chokes, particularly the rear naked choke. The key is maintaining proper control, preventing escapes, and setting up submissions.",bestResponse:"To escape back control, immediately try to remove the hooks and turn into the opponent. Keep your chin down and protect your neck. Don't let the opponent establish control or set up chokes. Use proper technique to escape and face the opponent."},{id:"guard-pull",name:"Guard Pull",category:"Takedowns",origin:"The guard pull is a BJJ-specific technique that was developed as a way to bring the fight to the ground when standing grappling wasn't effective. It became popular in BJJ competition and is now a fundamental technique for BJJ practitioners. The technique is named for the action of pulling the opponent into your guard.",description:"The guard pull is a technique where you pull the opponent into your guard by controlling their gi or body and sitting down. It's used to bring the fight to the ground and establish guard position. The key is proper grip control, timing the pull, and immediately establishing guard position.",bestResponse:"To counter a guard pull, immediately try to prevent the opponent from establishing guard position. Use proper posture and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them control your movement or set up submissions. Use the opportunity to establish a dominant position."},{id:"double-leg-takedown",name:"Double Leg Takedown",category:"Takedowns",origin:"The double leg takedown is one of the most fundamental wrestling techniques, originating from various grappling traditions around the world. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a crucial technique for taking opponents to the ground. The technique is named for the use of both legs in the takedown.",description:"The double leg takedown is a technique where you shoot in and grab both of the opponent's legs, driving them to the ground. It's excellent for taking opponents down and establishing top position. The key is proper timing, good penetration, and driving through the opponent.",bestResponse:"To defend the double leg, immediately sprawl and try to prevent the opponent from getting to your legs. Use proper posture and try to control their upper body. Don't let them establish control or complete the takedown. Use the sprawl to counter and establish top position."},{id:"single-leg-takedown",name:"Single Leg Takedown",category:"Takedowns",origin:"The single leg takedown is another fundamental wrestling technique that has been used in various grappling traditions for centuries. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became an important technique for taking opponents to the ground. The technique is named for the control of one leg.",description:"The single leg takedown is a technique where you shoot in and grab one of the opponent's legs, driving them to the ground. It's excellent for taking opponents down and establishing top position. The key is proper timing, good penetration, and driving through the opponent.",bestResponse:"To defend the single leg, immediately try to prevent the opponent from getting to your leg. Use proper posture and try to control their upper body. Don't let them establish control or complete the takedown. Use proper technique to counter and establish top position."},{id:"scissor-sweep",name:"Scissor Sweep",category:"Sweeps",origin:"The scissor sweep is one of the most fundamental sweeps in BJJ, originating from traditional Japanese Jiu-Jitsu. It was adapted and refined by the Gracie family and remains a cornerstone technique in BJJ guard play. The technique is named for the scissoring action of the legs.",description:"The scissor sweep is a sweep from closed guard where you use your legs in a scissoring motion to sweep the opponent to one side. It's excellent for reversing position and establishing top control. The key is proper grip control, timing the sweep, and using your legs effectively.",bestResponse:"To defend the scissor sweep, immediately try to prevent the opponent from establishing the necessary grips. Use proper posture and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them control your movement or set up the sweep. Use the opportunity to establish a dominant position."},{id:"hip-bump-sweep",name:"Hip Bump Sweep",category:"Sweeps",origin:"The hip bump sweep is a fundamental sweep in BJJ that was developed as a way to sweep opponents from closed guard. It became popular due to its simplicity and effectiveness. The technique is named for the hip bumping action used to create the sweep.",description:"The hip bump sweep is a sweep from closed guard where you bump your hips up and use your arms to sweep the opponent to one side. It's excellent for reversing position and establishing top control. The key is proper timing, good hip movement, and using your arms effectively.",bestResponse:"To defend the hip bump sweep, immediately try to prevent the opponent from establishing the necessary grips. Use proper posture and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them control your movement or set up the sweep. Use the opportunity to establish a dominant position."}];

sourcesContent:
export interface Technique {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  category: string;
  origin: string;
  description: string;
  bestResponse: string;
}

export const techniques: Technique[] = [
  {
    id: "armbar",
    name: "Armbar (Juji Gatame)",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The armbar is one of the most fundamental submissions in BJJ, originating from traditional Japanese Jiu-Jitsu. It was adapted and refined by the Gracie family in Brazil, becoming a cornerstone technique in modern BJJ. The name 'Juji Gatame' comes from Japanese, where 'Juji' means cross and 'Gatame' means lock.",
    description: "The armbar is a joint lock that hyperextends the elbow joint by placing the opponent's arm between your legs and applying pressure. From guard, mount, or side control, you isolate one arm, secure it between your thighs, and arch your hips to create the submission. The key is controlling the opponent's posture and preventing them from stacking or escaping.",
    bestResponse: "The best defense against an armbar is to prevent it before it's fully locked. Keep your elbows close to your body, maintain good posture, and never let your opponent isolate your arm. If caught, immediately try to stack the opponent, grab your own gi or belt to relieve pressure, or roll to escape. Always protect your arm by keeping it bent and close to your chest."
  },
  {
    id: "triangle-choke",
    name: "Triangle Choke (Sankaku Jime)",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The triangle choke was developed in Judo and later perfected in BJJ. It's named for the triangular shape created by your legs around the opponent's neck and arm. The technique became popular in BJJ due to its effectiveness from the guard position and was famously used by many Gracie family members.",
    description: "The triangle choke is a blood choke that cuts off blood flow to the brain by compressing the carotid arteries. You wrap your legs around the opponent's neck and one arm, creating a figure-four lock with your legs. The key is proper angle and hip movement to create maximum pressure on the neck while controlling the opponent's posture.",
    bestResponse: "To defend the triangle, immediately posture up and try to stack the opponent. Keep your head up and your arm that's inside the triangle close to your body. If you can't escape, try to pass the guard to relieve pressure. Never let your opponent control your posture or get the proper angle for the choke."
  },
  {
    id: "rear-naked-choke",
    name: "Rear Naked Choke (Hadaka Jime)",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The rear naked choke is one of the oldest and most effective submission techniques, originating from traditional Japanese martial arts. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a fundamental technique for back control. The name 'Hadaka Jime' means 'naked strangle' in Japanese, referring to the fact that no gi is needed.",
    description: "The rear naked choke is applied from the back position, where you wrap your arm around the opponent's neck and secure it with your other arm. The technique cuts off blood flow to the brain by compressing the carotid arteries. The key is proper hand placement, keeping your elbows close, and using your body weight to apply pressure.",
    bestResponse: "The best defense is to prevent your opponent from taking your back. If they do get back control, immediately protect your neck with your hands and try to peel their arms off. Keep your chin down and try to turn into them to relieve pressure. If caught in the choke, tap immediately as it can cause unconsciousness quickly."
  },
  {
    id: "kimura",
    name: "Kimura Lock (Gyaku Ude Garami)",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The Kimura lock is named after Masahiko Kimura, the legendary Japanese Judoka who famously used it to defeat Helio Gracie in 1951. The technique was originally called 'Gyaku Ude Garami' in Judo, meaning 'reverse arm entanglement.' It became a fundamental technique in BJJ and is now one of the most versatile submissions.",
    description: "The Kimura is a shoulder lock that applies pressure to the shoulder joint by controlling the opponent's wrist and applying rotational force. It can be applied from various positions including guard, side control, and mount. The key is controlling the opponent's wrist, keeping it close to their body, and using your body weight to apply the lock.",
    bestResponse: "To defend the Kimura, keep your elbows close to your body and never let your opponent isolate your arm. If they do get the grip, immediately try to roll or escape before they secure the position. You can also try to counter with your own Kimura or use the grip to sweep or pass guard."
  },
  {
    id: "guillotine",
    name: "Guillotine Choke",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The guillotine choke is a fundamental front headlock submission that has been used in various grappling arts for centuries. It became particularly popular in BJJ due to its effectiveness against aggressive opponents and its versatility from various positions. The name comes from the French execution device due to the similar action of the choke.",
    description: "The guillotine is a front headlock where you wrap your arm around the opponent's neck and apply pressure with your body weight. It can be applied as a blood choke or air choke depending on the variation. The key is proper hand placement, keeping your elbow close to your body, and using your hips to apply pressure.",
    bestResponse: "To defend the guillotine, immediately try to pass the guard or stack the opponent. Keep your head up and try to posture out of the choke. If you can't escape, try to roll to relieve pressure. Never let your opponent control your posture or get the proper angle for the choke."
  },
  {
    id: "omoplata",
    name: "Omoplata (Ashi Sankaku Garami)",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The omoplata is a shoulder lock that originated in Judo as 'Ashi Sankaku Garami' (leg triangle entanglement). It was adapted and refined in BJJ, particularly by the Gracie family. The name 'omoplata' comes from the Portuguese word for 'shoulder blade,' which is the target of the technique.",
    description: "The omoplata is a shoulder lock that uses your leg to control the opponent's arm and apply pressure to their shoulder joint. From guard, you wrap your leg around the opponent's arm and use your hips to create the lock. The technique can also be used as a sweep or transition to other submissions.",
    bestResponse: "To defend the omoplata, immediately try to roll or escape before your opponent secures the position. Keep your arm close to your body and try to posture up. If caught, you can try to roll to relieve pressure or use the position to counter with your own techniques."
  },
  {
    id: "heel-hook",
    name: "Heel Hook",
    category: "Submissions",
    origin: "The heel hook is a leg lock that has been used in various grappling arts for centuries. It became particularly popular in modern BJJ and submission grappling due to its effectiveness and the rise of leg lock specialists. The technique targets the knee joint and can cause serious injury if applied incorrectly.",
    description: "The heel hook is a leg lock that applies rotational force to the knee joint by controlling the opponent's heel and twisting. It can be applied from various positions including the saddle, 50/50, and other leg entanglement positions. The key is proper control of the opponent's leg and applying the lock gradually.",
    bestResponse: "The best defense is to prevent your opponent from securing leg control. If they do get a leg lock position, immediately try to escape or counter. Keep your legs active and try to prevent them from isolating your leg. If caught in a heel hook, tap immediately as it can cause serious knee injury."
  },
  {
    id: "de-la-riva-guard",
    name: "De La Riva Guard",
    category: "Guard",
    origin: "The De La Riva guard was developed by Ricardo De La Riva, a Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu black belt under Carlson Gracie. He created this innovative guard variation in the 1980s, which uses a hook behind the opponent's leg to control their movement and create sweeping opportunities. The technique revolutionized modern BJJ guard play.",
    description: "The De La Riva guard is an open guard variation where you hook your leg behind the opponent's leg while controlling their sleeve and collar. This creates a strong control point that allows for various sweeps and submissions. The key is maintaining proper distance, controlling the opponent's posture, and using the hook to off-balance them.",
    bestResponse: "To counter the De La Riva guard, immediately try to remove the hook by stepping back or using your free leg to kick it off. Control the opponent's legs and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them establish control of your sleeves or collar, and maintain good posture to prevent sweeps."
  },
  {
    id: "berimbolo",
    name: "Berimbolo",
    category: "Guard",
    origin: "The berimbolo was developed by the Mendes brothers (Rafael and Guilherme) in the early 2000s. It's a modern guard technique that involves inverting and rolling to take the opponent's back. The name 'berimbolo' comes from a Brazilian Portuguese word meaning 'trick' or 'gimmick,' reflecting its innovative nature.",
    description: "The berimbolo is a complex guard technique that involves inverting your body and rolling to take the opponent's back. It's typically set up from De La Riva guard or other open guard positions. The key is proper grip control, timing the inversion, and maintaining control throughout the movement.",
    bestResponse: "To defend the berimbolo, immediately try to prevent the inversion by controlling the opponent's legs and maintaining good posture. Don't let them establish the necessary grips, and try to pass the guard before they can set up the technique. If they do invert, try to counter with your own techniques."
  },
  {
    id: "butterfly-guard",
    name: "Butterfly Guard",
    category: "Guard",
    origin: "The butterfly guard was developed in BJJ as a way to create space and generate power for sweeps. It's named for the butterfly-like movement of the legs when executing sweeps. The technique became popular due to its effectiveness in both gi and no-gi competition.",
    description: "The butterfly guard is an open guard variation where you place your feet in the opponent's hips or thighs and use your legs to control their movement. It's excellent for creating sweeps and maintaining distance. The key is proper foot placement, controlling the opponent's posture, and using your legs to generate power for sweeps.",
    bestResponse: "To counter the butterfly guard, immediately try to control the opponent's legs and prevent them from establishing hooks. Use pressure to flatten them out and try to pass the guard quickly. Don't let them control your posture or get the proper angle for sweeps."
  },
  {
    id: "half-guard",
    name: "Half Guard",
    category: "Guard",
    origin: "The half guard is one of the oldest and most fundamental guard variations in BJJ. It's a transitional position that occurs when the opponent has passed part of your guard but you still have one leg trapped. The technique has been refined over decades and remains a crucial position in modern BJJ.",
    description: "The half guard is a position where you have one leg trapped between the opponent's legs while the other leg is free. It's excellent for sweeps, submissions, and regaining full guard. The key is controlling the opponent's posture, using your free leg effectively, and creating opportunities to sweep or submit.",
    bestResponse: "When in top half guard, immediately try to flatten the opponent and prevent them from regaining full guard. Control their upper body and try to pass quickly. Don't let them establish grips or create space for sweeps. Use pressure to control the position."
  },
  {
    id: "closed-guard",
    name: "Closed Guard",
    category: "Guard",
    origin: "The closed guard is the most fundamental guard position in BJJ, originating from traditional Japanese Jiu-Jitsu. It was adapted and refined by the Gracie family and remains the foundation of BJJ guard play. The position is named for the closed nature of the legs around the opponent.",
    description: "The closed guard is a position where you wrap your legs around the opponent's waist and lock your ankles together. It's excellent for controlling the opponent, setting up submissions, and preventing them from passing. The key is maintaining the guard, controlling the opponent's posture, and using your legs and hips effectively.",
    bestResponse: "To pass the closed guard, immediately try to break the guard by standing up or using pressure. Control the opponent's hips and prevent them from controlling your posture. Don't let them establish grips or set up submissions. Use proper technique to open the guard and pass quickly."
  },
  {
    id: "mount",
    name: "Mount Position",
    category: "Positions",
    origin: "The mount position is one of the most dominant positions in grappling, originating from traditional Japanese martial arts. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a fundamental position for control and submissions. The position is named for the mounted position, similar to riding a horse.",
    description: "The mount is a dominant position where you sit on the opponent's chest with your legs on either side of their body. It's excellent for control and setting up various submissions including armbars, triangles, and chokes. The key is maintaining proper balance, controlling the opponent's arms, and preventing escapes.",
    bestResponse: "To escape the mount, immediately try to bridge and roll or use the elbow escape. Keep your arms close to your body and try to create space. Don't let the opponent establish control or set up submissions. Use proper technique to escape and regain guard."
  },
  {
    id: "side-control",
    name: "Side Control",
    category: "Positions",
    origin: "Side control is a fundamental position in grappling that has been used in various martial arts for centuries. It was adopted into Judo and then BJJ, where it became a crucial position for control and submissions. The position is named for the side-by-side nature of the bodies.",
    description: "Side control is a dominant position where you lie perpendicular to the opponent, controlling their upper body with your weight and positioning. It's excellent for control and setting up various submissions including kimuras, armbars, and chokes. The key is maintaining proper pressure and preventing escapes.",
    bestResponse: "To escape side control, immediately try to bridge and roll or use the shrimp escape. Keep your arms close to your body and try to create space. Don't let the opponent establish control or set up submissions. Use proper technique to escape and regain guard."
  },
  {
    id: "back-control",
    name: "Back Control",
